Fig. 1 XRD patterns for perovskite supports and 6.3 wt% NiO /perovskite catalysts samples. * – NiO. Fig. 2 HAADF-STEM with EDX images for 6.3 wt% NiO / La(Cr0.2Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2)O3. Fig. 3 La3d + Ni2p (a), Cr2p (b), Ti2p (c), Mn2p (d), Fe2p (e), Co2p (f), O1s (g) and C1s (h) XPS spectra for perovskite supports and 6.3 wt% NiO /perovskite catalysts samples. Fig. 4 Temperature-programmed isotope exchange of oxygen with C18O2 in a flow reactor for (a) LM (1,1′), LCMFCN (2,2′), LTMFCN (3,3′) and (b) NiO/LM (1,1′), NiO/LCMFCN (2,2′) and (b) NiO/LTMFCN (3,3′): temperature dependencies of mole fractions of 18O atoms (α; 1,2,3) and C16O18O molecules (f 16–18, 1′,2′,3′). Points – experiment, lines – modeling. Fig. 5 Arrhenius plots for oxygen tracer diffusion coefficients for the LaMO3 (a) and NiO (6.3 wt%)/LaMO3 (b) according to the TPIE C18O2 data, where LaMO3 = LaMnO3 (1), La(Cr0.2Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2)O3 (2) and La(Ti0.2Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2)O3 (3). Fig. 6 HR TEM image for the Ni/La(Cr0.2Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2)O3 (a) and LaMnO3 (b) after test in ethanol dry reforming. Graphical abstract Ethanol dry reforming is a promising way to produce syngas and hydrogen due to utilization of carbon dioxide and ability to produce ethanol using renewable sources. Main problem associated with ethanol dry reforming reaction is coke formation. Coking suppression can be achieved in a few ways including use of catalysts possessing required oxygen transport properties. High entropy oxides are of interest in application as catalysts for ethanol dry reforming and other reactions due to their structural stability, disordering features and tunability of functional properties. In this work, the catalysts based on Ni and multiple doped La manganites are studied. The oxides are synthesized by modified Pechini and citrate techniques, and the catalysts are prepared by wetness impregnation. The samples are characterized by XRD, TEM with EDX analysis, XPS. Oxygen transport and redox properties are studied by temperature-programmed isotope exchange of oxygen and reduction. According to structural and morphological studies, the samples are nanosized and form perovskite-like structure. The surface features of samples were characterized by XPS. The samples demonstrate a moderate oxygen mobility (D* up to ∼10–12 cm2/s at 700 °C) required for catalytic operation and coking suppression. Tests in ethanol dry reforming demonstrated fine performance and good stability in the reaction conditions. Keywords Bioethanol Carbon dioxide Dry reforming High-entropy oxides Oxygen diffusion Isotope exchange Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction A great interest in ethanol dry reforming (EDR) is due by possibility of carbon dioxide utilization as a greenhouse gas and its conversion into syngas which can be further used as a fuel, a source of hydrogen gas, and transformed into various valuable chemicals. This is a good alternative to dry reforming of hydrocarbons, which source is in general non-renewable, while ethanol (bioethanol) can be produced using biomass as renewable source [1–3]. In the ideal case, the EDR reaction would result in forming the syngas with H2:CO ratio 1:1: C 2 H 5 OH g + CO 2 ⇆ 3 H 2 g + 3 CO g , Δ r H 298 K ° = 296 . 8 kJ/mol. The main advantage of EDR is the use of renewable ethanol. The main disadvantages are coke formation, sintering and spending valuable ethanol [2–5]. The main sources of coke are Boudouard reaction: 2 CO ⇆ CO 2 + C , Δ r H 298 K ° = - 172 kJ/mol, and methane pyrolysis (thermal decomposition) reaction: CH 4 ⇆ C + 2 H 2 , Δ r H 298 K ° = 75 kJ/mol, which occur simultaneously with the main EDR reaction route. Coke can contain various solid carbon products depending on the catalyst and reaction conditions, from amorphous and graphitic carbon to carbon monofilaments and fibers [2,6–8], and the latter ones are potentially valuable for using in optics, photonics, sensing applications, etc. [9,10]. Coking can be suppressed by using catalysts possessing a high oxygen mobility and surface reactivity [7,11], using additives to the catalyst composition such as alkali metal oxides [8], and using gaseous additives in the reaction mixture such as ammonia, hydrazine, etc., which increase the hydrogen yield as well [12]. The important problem related to EDR is design of highly efficient and stable to coking catalysts. In general, catalysts for EDR are comprised of metal active component and oxide support. Typically, there are Ni-based catalysts, e.g. Ni/Al2O3, which can in some EDR conditions reversibly transform into NiAl2O4 spinel [1–3,7,11,13]. Other non-noble and noble metals such as Co [3], Cu [3,13,14], Fe [6], Ir [2,3], Rh [3,15], etc. [1–3,11] have been used as well. Using bimetallic catalysts may result in coking decrease [3]. The oxide supports often consist of simple oxides such as Al2O3, MgO, SiO2, CeO2 etc. [2,3,13,16], as well as their composites with other simple oxides (NiO, ZrO2, La2O3, etc.) [15]. Among complex oxides, fluorite-like Ce-Zr-O oxides doped with various cations (Pr, Sm, Nb, Ti, etc,) and Y-stabilized zirconia are used [3,7,11,14]. Spinels such as doped MgAl2O4, Mn3-xCrxO4 have been applied as well [7,11]. Perovskites and Ruddlesden – Popper phases based on La ferrites, nickelates, cuprates and manganites are of a special interest, since they are active by themselves and can be used without addition of other metallic components due to their high oxygen mobility (via vacancy or cooperative mechanism [11,17–20]) and surface reactivity, acid-base properties and ability to exsolve metal nanoparticles which possess a high stability and excellent catalytic properties [11,18,21–27]. Ag, La, Ce and their compounds can be used as promotors [2,3,13]. One of modern topics associated with developing efficient catalysts for EDR and other reactions and their supports is related to high entropy oxides (HEO) [28–32]. HEO may possess a unique combination of functional properties. For HEO, a large number of cations occupying the same site being able to form vast numbers of possible elemental combinations results in the configurational disorder, which can affect the functional properties, and to the entropy stabilization of the structure, where entropy acts as a driving force for single-phase stabilization [29,31,32]. HEO with variable structure, controllable chemical composition, and rich functional properties are promising as catalysts and supports due to collective effect of their multi-component confined in the same lattice, and the oxygen defects caused by the lattice distortion [28–30]. Moreover, compared to low entropy oxides, some HEO are able to accumulate more oxygen vacancies and provide more oxygen migration pathways, hence, affecting the oxygen transport properties, which are highly important for fine catalyst performance and coking suppression [11,29,30]. HEO with perovskite [28–30,32–35], fluorite [28–30,32,35], bixbyite [29,32], pyrochlore [29,32] and rock salt [28–30,32,35] and other structures [28–30,32] have been studied as materials for catalytic, electrochemical and other applications. The catalytic activity of HEO with perovskite structure in the ethanol dry reforming has never been explored. This work aims at studying structural, textural, surface, oxygen transport, redox and catalytic properties for EDR catalysts based on Ni and multi-doped LaMnO3. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalysts synthesis LaMnO3 (LM) and La(Cr0.2Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2)O3 (LCMFCN) samples were synthesized via Pechini technique as described elsewhere [36], and La(Ti0.2Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2)O3 (LTMFCN) samples were synthesized via citrate method [37]. Final calcination temperature was 700 °C in the air. Ni/LM, Ni/LCMFCN and Ni/LTMFCN catalysts with 5 wt% Ni were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation of obtained oxides with a water solution of Ni(NO3)2 followed by drying and calcination at 700 °C in the air. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The samples’ phase composition was studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD). XRD studies were carried out using a Tongda TD-3700 (China) diffractometer within 2θ range of 10–70° with a step of 2θ = 0.05° using CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Unit cell parameters were calculated using Rietvield refinement. The size of the coherent scattering domain was calculated using Scherrer equation. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR TEM) images were obtained with a JEM-2010 (Jeol, Japan; lattice resolution 1.4 Å, acceleration voltage 2·105 V) and a Tescan Solaris (The Czech Republic) instruments. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) mapping was carried out using a UltimMAX100 (Oxford, The UK) SDD detector. The specific surface area was determined by BET method from the Ar thermal desorption data with the accuracy ±10 % using an ASAP 2400 (Micromeritics) apparatus. The surface properties of samples were characterized by the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). XPS spectra were recorded using a photoelectron spectrometer (SPECS, Berlin, Germany) equipped with a PHOIBOS-150-MCD-9 hemispherical analyzer and an XR-50X-ray source operated at 150 W. The Mg Kα radiation (1253.6 eV) was used for excitation. The powdered samples were supported on a double-sided Cu conducting tape. The samples were heated using an e-beam bombardment sample heating. The temperature was controlled via the type K thermocouple. After pretreatment sample were cooled down to room temperature and pumped out to ultra high vacuum conditions. The base pressure in the analyzer chamber was 5·10–9 mbar. The calibration of the spectrometer energy scale was performed using Au4f7/2 (84.0 eV) and Cu2p3/2 (932.7 eV) core-level lines. Spectral analysis and deconvolution were carried out using the XPS Peak 4.1 software [38]. All photoelectron spectra were preliminarily calibrated against the C1s peak position (284.8 eV) [39]. The determined integral intensities of photoelectron peaks were normalized by the corresponding atomic sensitivity factors [40]. Redox properties of samples pretreated in O2 at 500 °C were studied by the temperature- programmed reduction by H2 (H2-TPR) with the temperature ramp 10 °C/min from 60 to 900 °C using 10 % H2 in Ar mixture and GC Tsvet 500 (Russia) to record hydrogen content following earlier described procedure [41–43]. The oxygen mobility of samples was studied by the temperature-programmed isotope exchange of oxygen (TPIE) with C18O2 in a flow reactor. A sample (weight 50 mg, fraction 0.25–0.5 mm) was loaded into the quartz tube reactor with the inner diameter of 3 mm. Samples were pretreated in the flow of 1 % O2 + He (flowrate 25 ml/min) at 700 °C for 30 min and cooled down to 50 °C. TPIE experiments were carried out in a flow of He + 1 % C18O2, a flow rate of 25 mL min−1, while heating from 50 °C to 700 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1. The outlet gas composition was monitored by a SRS QMS-200 (Stanford Research Systems, USA) mass spectrometer. The 18O atomic fraction (α) and the C16O18O molecules’ fraction (f 16–18) were calculated as follows (Fig. S1 in Supplementary materials): α = 0.5 I 46 + I 48 I 44 + I 46 + I 48 , f 16 - 18 = I 46 I 44 + I 46 + I 48 , where I 44, I 46 and I 48 are the intensities of peaks with m/z = 44 a.m.u., 46 a.m.u. and 48 a.m.u., respectively. The estimation of the oxygen fraction exchanged (xe ) was carried as follows: x e = 1 n O , t o t a l · 2 · φ CO 2 u V m ∫ 0 t α input - α t d t · 100 %, where nO,total is the total amount of oxygen in the sample, φ CO 2 is the carbon dioxide volume fraction in the gas phase, u is the flow rate, Vm is the molar volume of ideal gas, αinput is the 18O atomic fraction in the reactor inlet. The calculation of oxygen tracer diffusion coefficient (D*) and its effective activation energy (ED ) was carried out by mathematical modeling using the α(T) and f 16-18(T) curves [42–45]: ∂ α ∂ t + 1 τ ∂ α ∂ ξ = - N s N g 0.5 R 1 + R 2 α - α s , ∂ f 16 - 18 ∂ t + 1 τ ∂ f 16 - 18 ∂ ξ = R 0 2 α 1 - α - f 16 - 18 + R 1 α s 1 - α + α 1 - α s - f 16 - 18 + R 2 2 α s 1 - α s , ∂ α s ∂ t = 0.5 R 1 + R 2 α - α s - N bulk N s D ∗ L 2 ∂ α bulk ∂ η , ∂ α bulk ∂ t = D ∗ L 2 ∂ 2 α bulk ∂ η 2 , where τ is the contact time; ξ is the dimensionless length of the sample layer; Ng is the number of all carbon dioxide molecules (including C16O2, C16O18O and C18O2) in the gas phase; Ns and Nbulk are the numbers of oxygen atoms in the sample surface and bulk, respectively; R 0, R 1 and R 2 are isotope exchange rates via I (homoexchange) and II (single-atomic heteroexchange) and III (two-atomic heteroexchange) types of mechanism according to the Muzykantov’s classification [46]; αs and αbulk are the 18O atomic fraction in the sample surface and bulk, respectively; L is the diffusion length; η is the dimensionless remoteness from the sample surface. Initial and boundary conditions are following: t = 0 : α = α s = α bulk = f 16 - 18 = 0 , ξ = 0 : α = α input , f 16 - 18 = f 16 - 18 input , η = 0 : α bulk = α s , η = 1 : ∂ α bulk ∂ η = 0 . This equation set was solved as follows. Differential operators with respect to ξ and η were replaced by their difference analogues with a second order of approximation. Further, a set of ordinary differential equations was solved using the Runge–Kutta–Merson method. The temperature dependencies of the exchange rate and the diffusion coefficient are assumed to obey the Arrhenius law (Fig. S2 in Supplementary materials): R i T = R i T ref e x p - E R i RT ' , D ∗ T = D ∗ T ref e x p - E D RT ' , T ′ = T T ref T ref - T , where Tref is the reference temperature; E R i and ED are the effective activation energies of Ri are D*, respectively; R is the universal gas constant. 2.3 Catalysts tests in ethanol dry reforming Test of the catalysts in the EDR reaction were performed using kinetic setup as described elsewhere [7,44,45]. The sample were loaded into the quartz reactor. Pretreatment was carried out in the flow of 5 % H2 + Ar at 600 °C for 1 h. Tests were carried out in the flow of 2 vol.% EtOH + 2 vol.% CO2 + Ar in the temperature range of 600–750 °C at contact time 10 ms. The gas analyzer with IR sensors for CO, CO2 and CH4, and electrochemical sensor for H2 (Boner LLC, Novosibirsk, Russia) was used for the reaction mixture analysis. Ethanol and carbon dioxide conversions and yields of hydrogen, methane and carbon monoxide were calculated as follows: X C 2 H 5 OH , % = C C 2 H 5 OH 0 - C C 2 H 5 OH C C 2 H 5 OH 0 × 100 % , X CO 2 , % = C CO 2 0 - C CO 2 C CO 2 0 × 100 % , Y H 2 , % = C H 2 3 C C 2 H 5 OH 0 × 100 % , Y CH 4 , % = C CH 4 C CO 2 0 + 2 C C 2 H 5 OH 0 × 100 % , Y CO , % = C CO C CO 2 0 + 2 C C 2 H 5 OH 0 × 100 % . The effective reaction rate constant (keff ) can be calculated in the approximation that the reaction is of the first order in ethanol according to the formula: k eff , s - 1 ≅ - ln 1 - X C 2 H 5 OH τ , where τ is the contact time (s). The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated by the following equation, where W0 (M s−1) is the rate at initial ethanol concentration, ρ (g/l) is the catalyst bulk density and NH (mol/gcat) is the number of moles of adsorbed hydrogen obtained by TPD-H2 [7]. TOF = W 0 ρ · N H 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase composition The XRD showed that all perovskite samples are single-phased corresponding to the hexagonal perovskite structure like LaMnO3 (space group R-3c, PDF 85-2152, Z = 6, or Pnma, PDF 30-713, Z = 4, where Z is the number of formula units) (Fig. 1 ). Absence of admixtures for HEO apparently evidences good solubility of doping cations in B-sublattice and entropy stabilization of single-phase composition. XRD analysis showed that mixed oxides contain small crystallites of the average size dXRD ∼ 20–40 nm. For the catalysts with supported Ni, the peaks at 2θ = 37.2, 43.3, 63.1° corresponding to the 111, 200, 220 reflections of NiO phase (space group Fm3m, PDF 47-1049) are visible. No admixture phases formation is detected (Fig. 1). One can see XRD peaks shift and peak splitting depending on the sample nature, which can be explained by a difference in unit cell parameters and average scattering region size (Table 1 ). Increasing unit cell parameters for high entropy (Ni/)LCMFCN and (Ni/)LTMFCN samples compared to those for the low entropy (Ni/)LM one can be explained by a variety of cation charge and size for the HEO samples [30,33,35], generation of defects and lattice distortion [28,30,33], the effect of M-O bond length and oxygen vacancy content [29,30], Deviation of unit cell parameters for samples with supported NiO compared to the NiO-free samples may indicate further lattice distortion due to the phase interaction. 3.2 Morphological and textural properties According to the BET studies, the specific surface area for initial HEO supports and after deposition of Ni for all catalysts is intermediate (15–18 m2/g), but high enough for using as catalysts. According to the TEM with EDX data, the particles are nanosized for all HEO samples which agrees with average scattering regions size according to the XRD data (Table 1, Fig. S3 in Supplementary materials). The particle shape is rather uniform, and they are connected into agglomerates with porous microstructure. According to transmission electron microscopy data, the presence of a large number of extended defects on the surface (grain boundaries, stacking faults, stairs/terraces) is characteristic. For all samples a large number of distortions is observed in the lattice fringes, which would promote the EDR process. HAADF-STEM with EDX analysis for HEO samples shows rather uniform distribution for all elements (Fig. 2 , Fig. S4 in Supplementary materials). According to the EDX analysis the elemental composition almost matches the designed one. By elemental mapping, all HEO supports seem to be single-phased, while the catalysts contain perovskite and NiO phases, which agrees with the XRD data. NiO nanoparticles are clearly visible on the catalysts. 3.3 Surface properties XPS spectra are demonstrated in Fig. 3 . Lanthanum is represented in the form of La3+ with a peak corresponding to La3d5/2 binding energy of 837.7 – 837.9, a satellite with BE ∼ 838 eV, and next two La3d3/2 peaks overlapping Ni2p3/2 (Fig. 3a) [36]. La3d spectra are typical for perovskites [47,48]. Nickel is presented in the form of Ni2+ characterized by Ni2p1/2 peak with BE = 872.1 – 872.3 eV. These Ni2+ cations belong to the perovskite phase for the HEO samples and apparently to both perovskite and NiO phases for the catalysts based on them. Chromium in Cr containing samples is presented in the form of Cr3+ with splitting into Cr2p3/2 peak with BE ∼ 576.1 – 576.5 eV and Cr2p1/2 peak with BE ∼ 586 eV (Fig. 3b). The BE for Cr2p3/2 peak differs from LaCrO3 [40], however, it is typical for various Cr-doped LaMeO3 perovskites [49–51]. Titanium in Ti −containing samples is represented by peak split into Ti2p3/2 and Ti2p1/2 with BE of 457.8–457.9 eV and ∼464 eV (Fig. 3c) corresponding to Ti4+ cations in perovskite structure [52,53]. Mn 2p peak with BE = 641.1–641.5 eV (Fig. 3d) corresponds to the state of Mn3+ [48,52,53]. Iron (Fig. 3e), according to the presence of peaks 710.4–710.5 eV (Fe2p3/2) and ∼724 eV (Fe2p1/2) is charged 3+ [48,50–52]. Cobalt cations generally possess a charge of 2+ (BE = 779.4–779.8 eV, Fig. 3f) [48,51,52,54]. O1s spectra contain two peaks with BE = 528.7–529.1 eV and 531.1 eV (Fig. 3g) corresponding to strongly bound lattice oxygen (Olatt) and weakly bound adsorbed oxygen (Oads), respectively [48,49,55–58]. The Olatt:Oads ratio calculated according to the peak area is 55:45, 70:30, 42:58 and 65:35 for the LCMFCN, LTMFCN, Ni/LCMFCN and Ni/LTMFCN samples, respectively. Contribution of each of these forms of oxygen varies from sample to sample apparently due to at least one of the following phenomena: variation of weakly bound oxygen content, different oxygen vacancy content and effect of NiO phase. The composition of the samples’ surface acquired from the XPS data is provided in Table S1 in Supplementary materials. As follows from this data, the surface composition strongly differs from the bulk one, which is close to the stoichiometric one. The surface is depleted by metals and enriched by oxygen. The oxygen atomic fraction on the surface of the samples slightly varies apparently due to different oxygen vacancy content. The ratio of A:B cations on the surface is below stoichiometric (∼0.6). This can be effect of some elements’ (such as Ni) segregation on the surface (as demonstrated by the TEM with EDX data, Fig. S2 in Supplementary materials). 3.4 Oxygen mobility According to the temperature-programmed isotope exchange with C18O2 data for LaMnO3, La(Cr0.2Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2)O3 and La(Ti0.2Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2)O3 samples (Fig. 4 a), there is a single minimum on α(T) curves corresponding to ∼80 % of total oxygen amount in the sample. Tracer diffusion coefficient values for this oxygen fraction are given in the Fig. 5 a and Table S2. The rest oxygen fraction possessed a lower mobility, however, its diffusion coefficient values cannot be estimated since the total fraction of oxygen exchanged during TPIE run is ∼60 %. As follows from Fig. 5b and Table S2, the D* values are close for the LM and LCMFCN samples, while it is significantly lower for the LTMFCN sample. A decrease of oxygen mobility for doped samples can be associated with decreasing oxygen vacancies content, since vacancy mechanism is a main mechanism of oxygen diffusion for perovskites [11,17–19,48,59,60]. Decreasing oxygen vacancy content is apparently related to substitution of B-site charged 3+ (and partially 4+) with cations with a higher charge such as Ti, which more tends to be charged 4+ than Mn (the charge of Mn and Ti according to the XPS data are 3 + and 4+, respectively) [61,62]: 2 Mn Mn × + V O ∙ ∙ + 2 TiO 2 ⇆ 2 Ti Mn ∙ + O O × + M n 2 O 3 It is also worth noting that the oxygen transport characteristics can be affected not only by the total oxygen vacancy content, but by mobile oxygen vacancy content as well, while some of the vacancies may become less mobile, e.g. due to their ordering induced by flexible charge of cations [63–66]. Moreover, a difference in Mn and Ti cations’ radii [67] results in changing the unit cell size (Table 1) and, probably, partially destroys Mn–O’s network resulting in increasing the resistivity of the material [61]. Similar effect probably takes place for the Cr-containing sample, since Cr cations in perovskites can have charge in the range of 2+ … 6+ [68]. However, the observed effect is less pronounced compared to that for the Ti-containing sample. The first probable reason is Cr cations in perovskite structure having the most probable charge of 3+ (at least, on the surface according to the XPS data) [69]. The second probable reason is related to partial distortion of LaMnO3 lattice while doping with Cr inducing the formation of oxygen defects and, thus, increasing the oxygen mobility, which is demonstrated by the temperature-programmed desorption of oxygen while comparing the data for undoped and Cr-doped La manganites [68]. Such a lattice distortion may be evidenced by variation of unit cell parameters according to the XRD data (Table 1) as well as the HR TEM data (Fig. 2). Lattice distortion of HEO can also cause distortion of M-O-M angles which results in increasing the ionicity of M-O bonds and, hence, increasing the oxygen mobility [70,71]. Hence, doping B-site of the La manganite with Ti decreases oxygen mobility which is probably determined by dopant effect on structural features and oxygen vacancy content, while doping with Cr almost does not result in significant variation of oxygen mobility. The effect of extended defects detected by HR TEM such as stacking faults, terraces, etc. can take place as well. Nevertheless, the oxygen mobility for all samples is moderate, which is high enough for their application as supports for catalysts being comparable or even exceeding that for supports such as Mn-Cr-O spinels [42] and Ce-Zr-O fluorites [44,45]. According to the TPIE data for catalysts based on NiO loaded on the perovskite supports mentioned above (Fig. 4b), for the Ni/LM and Ni/LTMFCN samples, there are two clearly distinguishable peaks at temperatures ∼500 and 700 °C corresponding to two forms of oxygen with the diffusion coefficients differing by ∼2–3 orders of magnitude (Fig. 5b, Table S1). For the Ni/LCMFCN sample, such difference in the mobility of oxygen forms is not observed. When analyzing the NiO effect on oxygen mobility, one can observe that for LaMnO3 addition of NiO results in a significant decrease in diffusion coefficient of the main oxygen fraction, while the diffusion coefficient of ∼12 % of oxygen is higher. For La(Ti0.2Mn0.2Fe0.2Ni0.2Co0.2)O3 the NiO addition almost does not affect the rate of substitution of the main oxygen fraction, however, it leads to emergence of the fast oxygen diffusion channel as well. For La(Cr0.2Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2)O3 the NiO addition almost does not affect the oxygen mobility. Such oxygen transport features of the catalysts studied are probably associated with the effect of the NiO phase possessing very low oxygen mobility [72,73] as well as possible effect of Ni cations dissolution in perovskite phase which can affect defect structure [11,74,75]. The lattice distortion which can take place due to a difference in the perovskite phase unit cell parameters for supports and catalysts, and extended defects observed by HR TEM can affect the oxygen transport properties. Additionally, difference in distribution of cations on the sample surface (Table S1) and ratio of oxygen forms (Fig. 3g) can make a contribution into the observed behavior of the oxygen mobility as well. 3.5 Redox studies by TPR H2 According to the H2 TPR data for the LM sample (Fig. S5), hydrogen consumption starts at low temperature with a low-intense peak at 190 °C apparently corresponding to removal of weakly bound surface oxygen [76,77]. The peaks at 325 and 430 °C are related to Mn cations reduction following by the peak at 818 °C apparently corresponding to the perovskite decomposition into La2O3 and MnO [48]. For the Ni/LM sample low-temperature region on H2 TPR curve is more smooth and broad. The peaks are shifted towards lower temperatures indicating decreasing stability to H2. The broad peak at 525 °C emerges apparently corresponding to NiO reduction to Ni0 [44,78]. The broadness of this peak can be explained by nonuniformity in NiO particle size which can be observed on the TEM data (Fig. 2). For the LCMFCN sample there are two distinguishable peaks at 325 and 380 °C in TPR H2 curves (Fig. S6) which can be associated with Fe3+ reduction into Fe2+ or/and removal of oxygen with the formation of oxygen vacancies [48,71,72]. Then, there is a continuous reduction at temperatures >600 °C which may correspond to Mn3+ reduction into MnO and Fe, Co and Ni cations reduction into Me0 state forming alloy dispersed on the oxides’ particles [48,54,76,77]. For the Ni/LCMFCN sample the peaks shifted towards lower temperatures again, and the broad peak emerging with maximum at 484 °C obviously corresponds to NiO reduction into metallic Ni [44,78]. For the LTMFCN and Ni/LTMFCN samples (Fig. S7), similar to the LM and Ni/LM ones, small low-temperature hydrogen consumption corresponds probably to removal of weakly bound oxygen species [76,77]. There is a broad shoulder followed by peaks at 377 and 394 °C for LTMFCN and Ni/LTMFCN samples, respectively, with next peaks at 480 and 484 °C for LTMFCN and Ni/LTMFCN samples, respectively. Due to a complex composition of samples, it is sophisticated to assign these curve shape features to separate phenomena. These phenomena can be proposed to be oxygen removal from the coordination sphere of highly charged cations (such as Ti4+) with formation of oxygen vacancies and reduction of Ti4+, Fe3+ and Ni2+ into Ti3+, Fe2+ and Ni0, respectively [44,51,54]. The peak corresponding to the NiO reduction into metallic Ni apparently overlaps the diffuse peak from the support. Then, there is a continuous reduction at temperatures >600 °C which may correspond to Mn3+ reduction into MnO and Fe, Co and Ni cations reduction into Me0 state forming alloy dispersed on the oxides’ particles [48,54,76,77]. Amount of hydrogen consumed is ∼10 mmol/g and it increases in the row of (Ni/)LTMFCN < (Ni/)LCMFCN < (Ni/)LM, thus demonstrating a good redox activity of supports and catalysts. The Ni reducibility estimated as described elsewhere [44] is ∼50 % for the Ni/LTMFCN catalyst which means that a fraction of Ni species is incorporated into the perovskite structure and is not reduced fully during TPR run. For the Ni/LM and Ni/LCMFCN catalysts the reducibility slightly exceed 100 %, which means that formation of metallic nickel particles led to an increase in the depth of support reduction due to hydrogen spillover [79,80]. 3.6 Catalytic tests in EDR reaction According to the test of the investigated catalysts in EDR reaction, almost total ethanol conversion is reached at temperatures of 700 °C and higher (Fig. S8, Table 2 ), however, conversion of carbon dioxide is not full even at 750 °C (Fig. S9 (b)), probably due to the effect of side reactions between the components of reaction mixture resulting in forming additional carbon dioxide [2,7,11]. With a decrease in temperature, a decrease in the conversion of ethanol and carbon dioxide is observed, which is in good agreement with the known thermodynamic dependencies [12,81]. It is to be noted that all catalysts exhibit close conversions in general at the temperatures above 650 °C, while the difference is mainly observed at lower temperatures, which can be related to the transport restrictions (such as gas-phase diffusion limitation) at high temperatures [7,22,82,83]. Hydrogen and carbon monoxide yields reach up to ∼50 % and ∼70 %, respectively, at 700–750 °C (Fig. S9a,b, Table 2). Methane yield temperature dependence goes through the maximum, however, it remains low (Fig. S9c), thus indicating that demethanation reaction occurs, then methane formed is fastly consumed to form other reaction products such as carbon monoxide and dioxide. H2:CO ratio (Table 2) is lower than 1 apparently due to the effect of reverse water gas shift reaction [2,7]. Estimation of its effective activation energy can be done in Arrhenius coordinates, and the initial rate W 0 and TOF are given in Table 3 , Fig. S10. Thus, modification of the complex oxide with chromium and titanium leads to an increase in catalytic activity, the most active catalyst is a sample doped with chromium. Earlier for Ru + Ni/MnxCr3-xO4 catalysts in ethanol steam reforming reaction it was shown that increasing content of Cr in mixed oxide support up to MnCr2O4 composition results in increasing specific catalytic activity (even TOF) despite decreasing oxygen mobility [42]. This implies participation of coordinative unsaturated surface Cr cations in activation of reagents and adsorbed intermediates (via C–C bond rupture in acetaldehyde, etc.) A high efficiency of Ru + Ni/MnCr2O4 active component in biofuels reforming was also demonstrated when it was supported on Mg-doped alumina [84]. Moreover, when doped by Cr mesoporous MgAl1.9Cr0.1O4 oxide was used as support for Ru + Ni/PrCeZrO active component, a high performance of this catalyst in methane and ethanol reforming was also obtained, explained again by participation of coordinatively unsaturated Cr cations in reagents activation [85]. Hence, a high activity of Cr-containing perovskite revealed in this work can be related to the catalytic efficiency of Cr cations on the surface of complex oxides. Titanium cations can form strong Lewis centers on the catalyst surface, which catalyze the ethanol dehydration reaction and may be the cause of coking as a result of the formation of a double C–C carbon bond. According to TPR-H2 data, for a titanium-containing sample the percentage of nickel reduction declines, thus decreasing the number of active centers and activity of the catalyst. There are some deviation from the Arrhenius dependence as shown in Fig. S10. E.g., at high temperature, the effective rate constant values for the Ni/LM and Ni/LCMFCN samples become slightly lower than expected. This can be related to such factors as the following [7,22,82,83]: • the transport limitations such as effects of gas-phase diffusion; • the effect of side reactions involving EDR reactants and products which can occur under such conditions including methane dry and steam reforming: CH4 + CO2 ⇆ 2H2 + 2CO, CH4 + H2O ⇆ 3H2 + CO, water–gas shift reaction: CO + H2O ⇆ CO2 + H2, etc.; • partial deactivation of the catalysts due to carbon formation on their surface (as discussed below); • a high error of the keff values estimation. According to post mortem TEM studies of spent catalysts (Figs. 6 and S11), Ni particles are clearly visible, Co segregation is observed as well. The other elements are distributed rather uniformly. The particles remain nanosized indicating the absence of significant sintering effects during catalytic tests. Some thread-like formations can be observed on HR TEM images probably corresponding to not numerous carbon nanofibers/nanofilaments, however, no massive coke aggregates are observed. TEM image with element mapping for the Ni/LCMFCN sample after catalytic tests showed no leaching of Cr, Fe and other cations. Fig. S12 (a) shows the data on the ethanol conversion and hydrogen yield in long-term tests for all catalysts. Almost total conversion of ethanol is reached which makes the quantitative comparison of the relative reactivity among the catalysts complicated. Decreasing the conversion can be reached by decreasing the contact time, which is planned to be implemented in the future work. For 5 h of the reaction, the conversion decreased slowly from 99 to 91 % for LCMFCN and from 86 to 75 % for LTMFCN, but for LM conversion decreased rapidly from 86 to 47 %, the main drop occurred for the first 3 h of reaction. The decrease in first hours is associated with the rapid carbon formation, as clearly shown in TEM image (Fig. 6 b). It was shown that the LM sample is characterized by whiskers carbon deposits and a significant amount of layers of carbon directly on the metal particles, which block active catalytic centers. Longer tests of the most active catalyst Ni/La(Cr0.2Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2)O3 showed its high activity and stability (Fig. S12b). High catalytic activity of samples is apparently related to a high dispersion of nanoparticles, rather high oxygen mobility and reducibility. The oxygen mobility is high enough to provide efficient participation of oxygen vacancies in EDR and oxygen species activity in suppression of coking. The formation of a fast diffusion channel involving relatively small amounts of oxygen would also enable the efficient catalyst operation. The better catalytic properties of the Cr-containing sample correlate with the higher mobility of the main oxygen fraction and its reducibility properties, as demonstrated by TPIE C18O2 and TPR H2, respectively. 4 Conclusions Phase composition, morphology, surface properties, oxygen mobility and redox activity of samples based on multiple-doped La manganites are studied. The samples are generally single-phased perovskites. The catalysts based on them contain Ni in the form of NiO. Both perovskite and NiO phases are nanosized as demonstrated by XRD and HR TEM. The surface properties studies and analysis of the ions’ state reveal the charge of cations, and two forms of surface oxygen differing in binding energy as well. The oxides demonstrate a moderate oxygen mobility, while for some catalysts additional fast oxygen diffusion channel forms characterized by diffusion coefficient up to ∼10–12 cm2/s at 700 °C. Such oxygen transport properties provide efficient operation of the catalyst and supress coke formation. TPR H2 studies reveal the features of reducibility of the samples including NiO and cations in perovskite phase. According to the tests in ethanol dry reforming reaction, total conversion of ethanol is reached at ∼700 °C. Hydrogen yield is ∼50 %. H2:CO ratio is below 1 which can be explained by the effect of the reverse water gas shift reaction. After the tests, no significant sintering of particles and massive coke formation is observed. Hence, the studied catalysts based on Ni and high entropy perovskites are promising for application in ethanol dry reforming. CRediT authorship contribution statement Nikita F. coredata.dc:description: Ethanol dry reforming is a promising way to produce syngas and hydrogen due to utilization of carbon dioxide and ability to produce ethanol using renewable sources. Main problem associated with ethanol dry reforming reaction is coke formation. Coking suppression can be achieved in a few ways including use of catalysts possessing required oxygen transport properties. High entropy oxides are of interest in application as catalysts for ethanol dry reforming and other reactions due to their structural stability, disordering features and tunability of functional properties. In this work, the catalysts based on Ni and multiple doped La manganites are studied. The oxides are synthesized by modified Pechini and citrate techniques, and the catalysts are prepared by wetness impregnation. The samples are characterized by XRD, TEM with EDX analysis, XPS. Oxygen transport and redox properties are studied by temperature-programmed isotope exchange of oxygen and reduction. According to structural and morphological studies, the samples are nanosized and form perovskite-like structure. The surface features of samples were characterized by XPS. The samples demonstrate a moderate oxygen mobility (D* up to ∼10–12 cm2/s at 700 °C) required for catalytic operation and coking suppression. Tests in ethanol dry reforming demonstrated fine performance and good stability in the reaction conditions.
